revision.text:
{{Use New Zealand English|date=July 2016}} {{use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Rosemary Askin | image = MG 6885Rosie1970.jpg | caption = Askin in [[Skelton Névé]], Antarctica (1970) | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1949}} | nationality = [[New Zealand]] | fields = Antarctic [[Geology]] | workplaces = [[Byrd Polar Research Center]]
[[Ohio State University]] | alma_mater = [[Victoria University of Wellington|Victoria University]], Wellington | known_for = }} '''Rosemary Anne Askin''' (born in 1949; also known as '''Rosemary Askin Cully''') is a New Zealand [[Geology|geologist]] specialising in [[Antarctic]] [[palynology]]. She was a trailblazer for women in Antarctic science, becoming the first [[New Zealand]] woman to undertake her own research programme in Antarctica in 1970.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fRJtB2MNdJMC|title=Encyclopedia of the Antarctic|last=Riffenburgh|first=Beau|date=2007-01-01|publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]]|isbn=9780415970242|language=en}} ==Early life and education== Born in 1949,{{Cite web|url=http://natlib.govt.nz/items?i%255Bsubject%255D=Askin%252C+Rosemary+Anne+(Dr)%252C+1949-&il%255Bsubject%255D=Burns%252C+Carolyn+Waugh%252C+1942-&il%255Busage%255D=Unknown|title=Page 1 of 1000 {{!}} Items {{!}} National Library of New Zealand|website=natlib.govt.nz|access-date=2016-06-24}} Askin earned both her BSc honours degree in geology and zoology and her PhD in geology from [[Victoria University of Wellington|Victoria University]], Wellington, New Zealand.{{Cite journal|date=2006-12-01|title=The authors|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/01916122.2006.9989626|journal=Palynology|volume=30|issue=1|pages=211–212|doi=10.1080/01916122.2006.9989626|issn=0191-6122}} ==Career and impact== Askin was a trailblazer for women in Antarctica. She was the first New Zealand woman to undertake her own scientific programme in Antarctica, as well as the first woman to work in a deep field setting in Antarctica, when in 1970 she conducted research in Victoria Land{{Cite web|url=http://www.zoominfo.com/CachedPage/?archive_id=0&page_id=-1777974906&page_url=//www.wisenet-australia.org/issue76/Women%2520in%2520Antarctica.htm&page_last_updated=2012-05-07T14:20:47&firstName=Rosemary&lastName=Askin|title=ZoomInfo Cached Page|website=www.zoominfo.com|access-date=2016-06-24}} at the age of 21. The expedition resulted in the discovery of Antarctica’s richest-known site of fossilised fish remains. The younger rocks in this area became the basis for Askin's PhD research.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3GbQsYgk4UsC|title=Victoria University of Wellington, 1899–1999: A History|last=Barrowman|first=Rachel|date=1999-01-01|publisher=[[Victoria University Press]]|isbn=9780864733696|language=en}} Askin received high praise for her geological work as well as her fortitude during the 1970–71 season, with Scott Base leader Brian Porter remarking that Askin had "gained the respect and admiration of all the men of the 1970–71 New Zealand Antarctic Research Programme and set a high standard for future women who may be involved in research in Antarctica, traditionally a man's world only".{{Cite journal|url=http://www.antarctic.org.nz/pdf/Antarctic/Antarctic.V6.1.1971.pdf|title=Women Scientists|last=|first=|date=March 1971|journal=Antarctic, a News Bulleting|volume=6|number=1|pages=2–3|access-date=}} Askin returned to the Antarctic numerous times between 1970 and 2001, completing expeditions to diverse parts of Antarctica including the Antarctic Peninsula, the South Shetland Islands, Victoria Land, and the [[Transantarctic Mountains]]. [[Mount Askin]] in the Darwin Mountains is named after her. Askin has researched and taught in several US universities, including The [[Ohio State University]], [[Colorado School of Mines]], and the [[University of California, Riverside]]. Askin's research interests include terrestrial palynology and the vegetational/palaeoenvironmental history of the Permian-Triassic and Cenozoic periods in Antarctica. Among other things, her research has examined fossil pollen and spores, fossilised over 350 million to a few million years ago, to see how vegetation has changed over time. In 1982, Askin also was a member of the research team that discovered the first mammal fossils in Antarctica,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/21/us/antarctica-yields-first-land-mammal-fossil.html|title=ANTARCTICA YIELDS FIRST LAND MAMMAL FOSSIL|last=Times|first=Robert Reinhold, Special To The New York|date=1982-03-21|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-06-24}} and she was involved in research that demonstrated that Antarctica experienced an abrupt warming cycle 15 million years ago.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailygalaxy.com/my_weblog/2010/06/abrupt-antarctica-warming-cycle-15-million-years-ago.html|title=Abrupt Antarctica Warming Cycle 15 Million Years Ago|website=The Daily Galaxy --Great Discoveries Channel|access-date=2016-06-24}}{{Cite journal|last=Warny|first=Sophie|last2=Askin|first2=Rosemary|last3=Hannah|first3=M.|last4=Mohr|first4=B.|last5=et. al.|first5=|date=2009|title=Palynomorphs from a sediment core reveal a sudden remarkably warm Antarctica during the middle Miocene|url=|journal=Geology|volume=37|issue=10|pages=955–958|doi=10.1130/G30139A.1|pmid=|access-date=|via=|bibcode=2009Geo....37..955W}} More recently, Askin spearheaded the establishment of the US Polar Rock Repository at the Byrd Polar Research Center, Ohio State University, the first repository of its kind.{{Cite web|url=https://researchnews.osu.edu/archive/rockrep.htm|title=Ohio State Rocks: Byrd Polar Center Home To National Rock Repository|website=researchnews.osu.edu|access-date=2016-06-24}} ==Personal life== Askin is a Tai Chi & Qigong and karate teacher,{{Cite web|url=http://www.jhnewsandguide.com/calendar/community/tai-chi-and-qigong-class/event_90c388fc-86f1-11e3-b10d-1f1b9a8b07a5.html|title=Tai Chi and Qigong class - Wyoming Karate Club|last=|first=|date=|website=jhnewsandguide.com|publisher=Jackson Hole News and Guide|access-date=}} and holds a 3rd Degree Black Belt (Sandan) in karate and a Tai Chi Advanced level (2013) from the Shorin-ryu Karatedo and Kobudo Association of America.{{Cite web|url=http://beisho.org/promotions.htm|title=Promotions and Awards|website=beisho.org|access-date=2016-06-24}} ==Selected publications== *Askin, Rosemary A. "Campanian to Paleocene palynological succession of Seymour and adjacent islands, northeastern Antarctic Peninsula." Geological Society of America Memoirs 169 (1988): 131–154. *Askin, Rosemary A. "Endemism and heterochroneity in the Late Cretaceous (Campanian) to Paleocene palynofloras of Seymour Island, Antarctica: implications for origins, dispersal and palaeoclimates of southern floras." Geological Society, London, Special Publications 47.1 (1989): 107–119. *Askin, Rosemary A. "Campanian to Paleocene spore and pollen assemblages of Seymour Island, Antarctica." Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology 65.1 (1990): 105-113. *Askin, Rosemary A. "Late Cretaceous–early Tertiary Antarctic outcrop evidence for past vegetation and climates." The Antarctic Paleoenvironment: a perspective on global change: Part One (1992): 61–74. *Isbell, John L., Paul A. Lenaker, Rosemary A. Askin, Molly F. Miller, and Loren E. Babcock. "Reevaluation of the timing and extent of late Paleozoic glaciation in Gondwana: Role of the Transantarctic Mountains." Geology 31, no. 11 (2003): 977–980. *Collinson, James W., Hammer, William R., Askin, Rosemary A. and David H. Elliot. "Permian-Triassic boundary in the central Transantarctic Mountains, Antarctica." Geological Society of American Bulletin 118 (5/6) (2006): 747-763, Data Repos. Item 2006080. *Warny, Sophie and Rosemary Askin. "Vegetation and organic-walled phytoplankton at the end of the Antarctic greenhouse world: latest Eocene cooling events." In Anderson, J.B. and Wellner, J.S. (Eds.), Tectonic, Climatic, and Cryospheric Evolution of the Antarctic Peninsula. American Geophysical Union, Washington, D.C. (2011): 193-210. ==References== {{Reflist|35em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Askin, Rosemary}} [[Category:New Zealand women scientists]] [[Category:New Zealand geologists]] [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Victoria University of Wellington alumni]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:Women Antarctic scientists]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/2601:602:9700:3091:9C59:D4B:3F4B:3CD1|2601:602:9700:3091:9C59:D4B:3F4B:3CD1]] ([[User talk:2601:602:9700:3091:9C59:D4B:3F4B:3CD1|talk]]): not providing a [[WP:RS|reliable source]] ([[WP:CITE]], [[WP:RS]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
{{slavery}} The practice of '''slavery in [[Vietnam]]''' persisted since the [[Hồng Bàng dynasty|Hồng Bàng period]]. Vietnam has been both a source and a destination for slaves.
==Hong Bang period== During the [[Hồng Bàng dynasty|Hồng Bàng period]], the society was divided into three classes consisting of kings, citizens and slaves. A slave, the lowest class, served the aristocracy.
==Chinese rule== During the [[Chinese domination of Vietnam|Chinese domination period]], Vietnamese girls were sold as sex slaves to the Chinese.<ref>Viet Nam History - Part 2 (Lịch Sử Việt Nam - phần 2) http://thuvienbao.com/books-literature/viet_history/VNHistory_2.htm http://www.vietlist.us/SUB_VietHistory/VNHistory_2.shtml</ref> A large trade developed where the native girls of Nam Viet were enslaved and brought north to the Chinese.<ref>Schafer (1967), p. 56 {{Google books|yaeESYegRXMC|The Vermilion Bird|page=56}}</ref><ref>Reilly (2003), p. 59 {{Google books|E_xkU5a5Ts0C|Racism: A Global Reader|page=59}}</ref><ref>Cartier (2011), https://books.google.com/books?id=TRuqcutRvUAC&pg=PT31#v=onepage&q&f=false</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cpamedia.com/article.php?pg=archive&acid=120510165245&aiid=120601122255|title= An Intimate Affair: Vietnam's Love-Hate Relationship With China|last1= Forbes|first1= Andrew|last2= |first2= |date= |website=cpa media |publisher= cpa media|accessdate=2 August 2013}}</ref><ref>Vietnam Past and Present: The North https://books.google.com/books?id=gKCea9iRga4C&pg=PT232#v=onepage&q&f=false</ref><ref>Schafer (1963), p. 44 {{Google books|9Z7cZ77SqEQC|The Golden Peaches of Samarkand: A Study of Tʻang Exotics|page=44}}</ref> Southern Yue girls were sexually eroticized in Chinese literature and in poems written by Chinese who were exiled to the south.<ref>Abramson (2011), p. 21 {{Google books|-GLGnRspmcAC|Ethnic Identity in Tang China|page=21}}</ref> But in fact, when Chinese poets are talking about Yue, they didn't mean Vietnam. Yue is an ancient calling of [[Zhejiang]]. So, Yue Girls means girls from Zhejiang instead of Vietnam slaves.
==Dynastic era== The Vietnamese enslaved enemy prisoners of war including the Chinese and Cham.
===Ly dynasty=== During the [[Lý dynasty]], Vietnam raided [[Song dynasty]] to enslave Chinese, who were forced to serve in the Vietnamese army as soldiers.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?ei=-nm6UND4OLSw0QHL9ICADQ&id=DIpRAQAAIAAJ&q=merchants+resold#search_anchor Journal of Southeast Asian studies, Volume 37, Issue 1 (2006), p. 87]</ref> Vietnamese Buddhist Temples received Cham slaves who were prisoners of war.<ref>Nguyen (1997), p. 347 {{Google books|mnLO4l5Kk64C|Zen in Medieval Vietnam: A Study and Translation of the Thiè̂n Uyẻ̂n Tập Anhpage=347}}</ref>
===Le dynasty===
After the [[Cham–Vietnamese War (1471)]] Cham prisoners were given as slaves to Vietnamese estates.<ref>Kiernan (2008), p. 110 {{Google books|R5p7cRyK748C|Blood and Soil: Modern Genocide 1500-2000|page=110}}</ref> They were all eventually ordered to be killed due to a royal order.<ref>Kiernan (2008), p. 111 {{Google books|R5p7cRyK748C|Blood and Soil: Modern Genocide 1500-2000|page=111}}</ref><ref>Taylor (1995), p. 46 {{Google books|A60OggwLPrAC|Essays Into Vietnamese Pasts|page=46}}</ref>
Emperor [[Lê Thánh Tông]] was aggressive in his relations with foreign countries including China and Malacca and cracked down on foreign trade and contacts, enforcing an isolationist policy. A large amount of trade between Guangdong and Vietnam happened during his reign. Early accounts recorded that the Vietnamese captured Chinese whose ships had blown off course and detained them. Young Chinese men were selected by the Vietnamese for castration to become [[eunuch]] slaves to the Vietnamese. It has been speculated by modern historians that the Chinese who were captured and castrated by the Vietnamese were involved in trade between China and Vietnam instead of actually being blown off course by the wind and they were punished as part of a crackdown on illegal foreign trade by Vietnam.<ref>{{cite Several Malay envoys from the [[Malacca Sultanate]] were attacked and captured in 1469 by Annam (Vietnam) as they were returning to Malacca from China. The Vietnamese enslaved and castrated the young from among the captured.<ref>Tsai (1996), p. 15 {{Google books|Ka6jNJcX_ygC|The Eunuchs in the Ming Dynasty (Ming Tai Huan Kuan)|page=15}}</ref><ref>Rost (1887), p. 252 {{Google books|TgkYAAAAYAAJ|Miscellaneous papers relating to Indo-China: reprinted for the Straits Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society from Dalrymple's "Oriental Repertory," and the "Asiatic Researches" and "Journal" of the Asiatic Society of Bengal, Volume 1|page=252}}</ref><ref>Rost (1887), p. 252 {{Google books|utZMAAAAYAAJ|Miscellaneous papers relating to Indo-China and Indian archipelage: reprinted for the Straits Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society. A 1472 entry in the ''[[Ming Shilu]]'' reported that when some Chinese from [[Nanhai District|Nanhai county]] escaped back to China after their ship had been blown off course into Vietnam, where they had been forced to serve as soldiers in Vietnam's military. The escapees also reported that they found out up to 100 Chinese men remained captives in Vietnam after they were caught and castrated by the Vietnamese after their ships were blown off course into Vietnam. The Chinese Ministry of Revenue responded by ordering Chinese civilians and soldiers to stop going abroad to foreign countries.<ref>{{harvnb|Wade|2005|p=[http://epress.nus.edu.sg/msl/entry/1706 2078/79]}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Chinese State at the Borders|year=2007|publisher=UBC Press|isbn=0774813334|url=http://www.history.ubc.ca/faculty/lshin/research/pdf/07_shin_ubcp.pdf|author=Leo K. Shin|edition=illustrated|chapter=Ming China and Its Border with Annam|editor=Diana Lary|accessdate=5 January 2013|page=92|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6JBWOD4cL?url=http://www.history.ubc.ca/faculty/lshin/research/pdf/07_shin_ubcp.pdf|archivedate=27 August 2013|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=明實錄 (Ming Shilu)|url=http://wenxian.fanren8.com/06/03/49/106.htm|accessdate=5 January 2013|language=Chinese|chapter=首页 > 06史藏-1725部 > 03别史-100部 > 49-明实录宪宗实录-- > 106-明宪宗纯皇帝实录卷之一百六|quote=Simplified Chinese:○癸亥广东守珠池奉御陈彝奏南海县民为风飘至安南国被其国王编以为军其后逸归言中国人飘泊被留及所为阉禁者百余人奏下户部请移文巡抚镇守等官禁约军民人等毋得指以□贩私通番国且令守珠军人设法堤备从之 Traditional Chinese:○癸亥廣東守珠池奉禦陳彝奏南海縣民為風飄至安南國被其國王編以為軍其後逸歸言中國人飄泊被留及所為閹禁者百余人奏下戶部請移文巡撫鎮守等官禁約軍民人等毋得指以□販私通番國且令守珠軍人設法堤備從之}}</ref><ref>《明宪宗实录》卷一百六，成化八年七月癸亥</ref> China's relations with Vietnam during this period were marked by the punishment of prisoners by castration.<ref>Tsai (1996), p. 16 {{Google books|Ka6jNJcX_ygC|The Eunuchs in the Ming Dynasty (Ming Tai Huan Kuan)|page=16}}</ref><ref>Tsai (1996), p. 245 {{Google books|Ka6jNJcX_ygC|The Eunuchs in the Ming Dynasty (Ming Tai Huan Kuan)|page=245}}</ref>
A 1499 entry in the Ming Shilu recorded that thirteen Chinese men from [[Wenchang]] including a young man named Wu Rui were captured by the Vietnamese after their ship was blown off course while traveling from [[Hainan]] to [[Guangdong]]'s Qin subprefecture ([[Qinzhou]]), after which they ended up near the coast of Vietnam, during the [[Chenghua Emperor]]'s rule (1447 - 1487) . Twelve of them were enslaved to work as agricultural laborers, while the youngest, [[Wu Rui]] (吳瑞) was selected for castration since he was the only young man and he became a eunuch attendant at the [[Imperial Citadel of Thăng Long|Vietnamese imperial palace in Thăng Long]]. After years of service, he was promoted at the death of the Vietnamese ruler in 1497 to a military position in northern Vietnam. A soldier told him of an escape route back to China and Wu Rui escaped to [[Longzhou County|Longzhou]]. The local chief planned to sell him back to the Vietnamese, but Wu was rescued by the [[Pingxiang, Guangxi|Pingxiang]] magistrate and then was sent to [[Beijing]] to work as a eunuch in the palace.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Chinese State at the Borders|year=2007|publisher=UBC Press|isbn=0774813334|url=http://www.history.ubc.ca/faculty/lshin/research/pdf/07_shin_ubcp.pdf|author=Leo K. Shin|edition=illustrated|chapter=Ming China and Its Border with Annam|editor=Diana Lary|accessdate=5 January 2013|page=91|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6JBWOD4cL?url=http://www.history.ubc.ca/faculty/lshin/research/pdf/07_shin_ubcp.pdf|archivedate=27 August 2013|df=}}</ref><ref name="Cooke 2011 p. 109">Cooke (2011), p. 109 {{Google books|7mlKjn3FfoMC|The Tongking Gulf Through History|page=109}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Wade|2005|p=[http://epress.nus.edu.sg/msl/entry/2183 2704/05]}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=明實錄 (Ming Shilu)|url=http://wenxian.fanren8.com/06/03/47/146.htm|accessdate=5 January 2013|language=Chinese|chapter=首页 > 06史藏-1725部 > 03别史-100部 > 47-明实录孝宗实录-- > 146-明孝宗敬皇帝实录卷之一百五十三|quote=Simplified Chinese:○金星昼见于辰位○辛卯吴瑞者广东文昌县人成化中与同乡刘求等十三人于钦州贸易遭风飘至安南海边罗者得之送本国求等俱发屯田以瑞独少宫之弘治十年国王黎灏卒瑞往东津点军得谅山卫军杨三知归路缘山行九日达龙州主头目韦琛家谋告守备官送还琛不欲久之安南国知之恐泄其国事遣探儿持百金为赎琛少之议未决而凭祥州知州李广宁闻之卒兵夺送于分守官都御史邓廷瓒遣送至京礼部请罪琛为边人之戒奖广宁为土官之劝从之瑞送司礼监给役 Traditional Chinese:○金星晝見於辰位○辛卯吳瑞者廣東文昌縣人成化中與同鄉劉求等十三人於欽州貿易遭風飄至安南海邊羅者得之送本國求等俱發屯田以瑞獨少宮之弘治十年國王黎灝卒瑞往東津點軍得諒山衛軍楊三知歸路緣山行九日達龍州主頭目韋琛家謀告守備官送還琛不欲久之安南國知之恐洩其國事遣探兒持百金為贖琛少之議未決而憑祥州知州李廣寧聞之卒兵奪送於分守官都御史鄧廷瓚遣送至京禮部請罪琛為邊人之戒獎廣寧為土官之勸從之瑞送司禮監給役}}</ref><ref>《明孝宗实录》卷一五三，弘治十二年八月辛卯</ref>
The [[Đại Việt sử ký toàn thư]] records that in 1467 in An Bang province of Dai Viet (now [[Quảng Ninh Province]]) a Chinese ship blew off course onto the shore. The Chinese were detained and not allowed to return to China as ordered by Le Thanh Tong.<ref>Cooke (2011), p. 108 {{Google books|7mlKjn3FfoMC|The Tongking Gulf Through History|page=108}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CÓ MỘT VÂN ĐỒN Ở GIỮA YÊN BANG, YÊN QUẢNG KHÔNG TĨNH LẶNG|author=PGS.TSKH Nguyễn Hải Kế(Associate Professor Dr. Nguyen Hai Ke)|url=http://khoalichsu.edu.vn/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=416:co-mt-van-n-gia-yen-bang-yen-qung-khong-tnh-lng-pgstskh-nguyn-hi-k&catid=25:bai-vit&Itemid=33|publisher=广州日报大洋网(www.dayoo.com)|date=28 March 2013 |accessdate=26 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=CÓ MỘT VÂN ĐỒN Ở GIỮA YÊN BANG, YÊN QUẢNG KHÔNG TĨNH LẶNG |author=PGS. TSKH Nguyễn Hải Kế (Associate Professor Dr. Nguyen Hai Ke) |url=http://duyhoang.net/co-mot-van-don-o-giua-yen-bang-yen-quang-khong-tinh-lang.htm |publisher=广州日报大洋网(www.dayoo.com) |date=2013-04-22 <!-- 18:56 --> |accessdate=26 July 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130727003650/http://duyhoang.net/co-mot-van-don-o-giua-yen-bang-yen-quang-khong-tinh-lang.htm |archivedate=27 July 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Đại Việt Sử Ký Toàn Thư |editors=Lê Văn Hưu, Phan Phu Tiên, Ngô Sĩ Liên... soạn thảo (1272 - 1697) |others=Viện Khoa Học Xã Hội Việt Nam dịch (1985 - 1992) |chapter=Phần 26 (Bản kỷ thực lục Q2(a), Nhà Hậu Lê (1460 - 1472).) |url= http://www.mtat.macdinhchi71.com/suutam/truyen/daivietsukytoanthu/hoi26.htm|publisher=Nhà xuất bản Khoa Học Xã Hội (Hà Nội) ấn hành (1993). |year=1993 |accessdate=26 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Đại Việt Sử Ký Toàn Thư |editors=Lê Văn Hưu, Phan Phu Tiên, Ngô Sĩ Liên... soạn thảo (1272 - 1697) |others=Viện Khoa Học Xã Hội Việt Nam dịch (1985 - 1992). |chapter=DVSK Bản Kỷ Thực Lục 12: Nhà Hậu Lê (1460 - 1472) ... Phần 1(Đại Việt Sử Ký Bản Kỷ Thực Lục, Quyển XII [1a], Kỷ Nhà Lê, Thánh Tông Thuần Hoàng Đế) |url= http://www.informatik.uni-leipzig.de/~duc/sach/dvsktt/dvsktt17a.html |publisher=Nhà xuất bản Khoa Học Xã Hội (Hà Nội) ấn hành (1993). |year=1993 |accessdate=26 July 2013}}</ref> This incident may be the same one where Wu Rui was captured.<ref name="Cooke 2011 p. 109"/>
===Nguyen lords rule=== The [[Dutch Formosa|Dutch in Taiwan]] owned Quinamese slaves (from [[Quảng Nam Province]]).<ref>Chiu (2008), p. 84 {{Google books|4QzpJtddFxEC|The Colonial 'civilizing Process' in Dutch Formosa: 1624 - 1662|page=84}}</ref><ref>Chiu (2008), p. 124 {{Google books|4QzpJtddFxEC|The Colonial 'civilizing Process' in Dutch Formosa: 1624 - 1662|page=124}}</ref>
===Nguyen dynasty=== The Vietnamese enslaved "barbarian" uplanders in [[Cochinchina]].<ref>Li (1998), p. 125 {{Google books|05x5UGA8MmAC|Nguyễn Cochinchina: Southern Vietnam in the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries |page=125}}</ref>
==Republican era== Since the 1980s, some [[Women in Vietnam|women from Vietnam]] have become victims of [[bride kidnapping|kidnapping]], the bride-buying trade, and [[Human trafficking in the People's Republic of China|human trafficking]] and [[Prostitution in China|prostitution]] in China.<ref name=WSJ>{{cite web |last1=Marshall |first1=Samantha |first2=Joanne |last2=Lee-Young |first3=Matt |last3=Forney |url=http://www.wright.edu/~tdung/bride_vn.htm |title=Vietnamese Women are Kidnapped and Later Sold in China as Brides |work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=3 August 1999|accessdate=2 May 2011}}</ref> The present-day struggle of the Vietnamese female victims of "[[International marriage agency|bride-broker]]s" can be summarized by the larger-than-life poem known as "[[The Tale of Kieu]]," which narrates the story of a female protagonist of Vietnam who was purchased by foreigners and was violated, yet kept fighting back against her captors and offenders.<ref name=WSJ/>
Human traffickers, such as in [[Bangkok]], trick, kidnap and detain the women for the purpose of raping them, making them [[surrogate mother]]s, and selling their babies to clients in [[Taiwan]].<ref name=DO>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfexaminer.com/opinion/daily-outrage/2011/02/14-vietnamese-women-rescued-breeding-gang |title=Daily Outrage: 14 Vietnamese women rescued from breeding gang |work=[[The San Francisco Examiner]] |date=25 February 2011 |accessdate=2 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120529054624/http://www.sfexaminer.com/opinion/daily-outrage/2011/02/14-vietnamese-women-rescued-breeding-gang |archivedate=29 May 2012 |df= }}</ref>
